awd_titl_txt: Roles of Regional Ocean-Atmosphere Coupling and Remote Forcing in Northwest Pacific Monsoon Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
Summer is the rainy season for East Asia. The Meiyu-Baiu rain band, extending from the eastern flank of the Tibetan Plateau northeastward through Korea and Japan, is the single most important climate phenomenon of the region. The termination of this summer rain band in late July has been tied to the abrupt onset of tropical convection over the Northwest Pacific east of the Philippines, through a meridional dipole pattern of summer rainfall variability. The abrupt onset of Northwest Pacific convection remains unsolved with local sea surface temperature (SST) rising above 28 degrees C as early as in June. 

Effort under this project will investigate the hypothesis that the gradual moistening of the lower troposphere via shallow convection leads to a threshold behavior of abrupt convective onset over the tropical Northwest Pacific. During the satellite era starting 1979, interannual variability in tropical Northwest Pacific convection is well correlated with El Nino/Southern Oscillation (ENSO). Specifically, an anomalous anticyclonic circulation (AAC) forms and rainfall decreases over the tropical Northwest Pacific in post-El Nino summers. Through earlier studies a positive feedback has been identified due to interactions between the AAC and Indo-Northwest Pacific SST during summer when the southwest monsoonal winds prevail. We will investigate the mechanisms and predictability of this regional coupled mode. 

The correlation between the AAC and ENSO breaks down during half of the 20th century from the 1920s and 1970s. Weak ENSO amplitudes are considered to have caused the low correlation. This aspect as well as the role of random noise due to atmospheric internal variability will be explored critically. Locally, Northwest Pacific convection affects the U.S. affiliated Northern Mariana Islands and Guam. Remotely, it affects the South and East Asian monsoon regions, home to three billion people. This research will help improve seasonal forecast and climate change projection in the regions, thereby contributing to several ongoing international research programs. The project trains the next generation of climate scientists by including graduate students and postdocs in the research team, and by exposing them to international collaborations.

por.por_cntn:
El Nino/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is the dominant mode of interannual climate variability in instrumental observations, with marked global influences including North America and Asia. It was a long-standing mystery that well-defined anomalies are observed in summers following, in addition to during, ENSO events. The PI?s earlier research contributed to solving the mystery by uncovering the Indo-western Pacific ocean capacitor (IPOC) effect. El Nino causes the tropical Indian Ocean to warm like a battery charging a capacitor, and the Indian Ocean warming outlasts El Nino and affects climate like a discharging capacitor. The capacitor effect includes rainfall anomalies over India and the Yangtze River basin of China, through a recurrent atmospheric pattern known as the anomalous anticyclonic circulation (AAC) that spans the North Indian Ocean and subtropical Northwest Pacific. Major advances were made during this NSF-funded project in following areas.

Intrinsic mode of the Asian summer monsoon

Kinetic energy analysis shows that so-called barotropic conversion energizes the AAC in the region where the monsoon westerly and easterly trade winds convergence. This unstable mechanism indicates that the AAC is an intrinsic mode of the Asian summer monsoon system and explains why it is recurrent at the intraseasonal, seasonal, and interannual cycle. At the interannual timescale especially, the AAC and Indo-western Pacific SST variability are coupled, yielding positive feedback that allows the coupled mode to persist through the post-ENSO summer. The southwesterly moisture flux on the northwest flank of the AAC causes excessive rainfall along the Yangtze River.

Non-ENSO variability.

Heavy rainfall caused a historic flooding of the Yangtze River in 2020 summer, displacing millions. This extreme rainy season was not anticipated from El Ni?o

conditions. Instead, we show that the record strong Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) event nine months earlier in 2019 is an important contributor to the extreme Yangtze flooding of 2020. This Indian Ocean mode and a weak El Ni?o in the Pacific excite downwelling oceanic Rossby waves that propagate slowly westward south of the equator, sustaining the Indian Ocean warming through the 2020 summer. The Indian Ocean warming forces the AAC in the lower troposphere over the Indo-Northwest Pacific region and intensifies the upper-level westerly jet over East Asia, leading to heavy rainfall in the Yangtze Basin. While official forecasts failed, dynamic models initialized with observed ocean state predicted this strong AAC event and heavy summer rainfall in the Yangtze Basin as early as April 2020.

The extreme summer of 2020 illustrates the importance of non-ENSO internal variability and the key role the AAC and IPOC play. It prompted the Japan Meteorological Agency and China Meteorological Administration to give more weight to dynamic model results in the official rainy-season forecast. It also heralded the Indian Ocean as a major driver of Asian monsoon variability to millions of people in East Asia through media reporting.

 

The project has produced 53 peer-reviewed publications, many in high-impact journals (15 in Nature or its sister journals, 1 each in Science, Science Advances, and PNAS). The results from the project were featured as journal covers (Nature Climate Change and Geophysical Research Letters), highlighted with commentary articles, and widely reported in the media. Three graduate students received their PhD degrees at UCSD, one receiving a Chancellor Dissertation Medal. The PI has completed a 400-page textbook on coupled ocean-atmosphere dynamics, to appear in early 2023.

Xie, S.-P., 2023: Coupled Atmosphere-Ocean Dynamics: From El Ni?o to Climate Change. Elsevier, 400 pages. ISBN: 9780323954907

Zhou, Z.-Q., S.-P. Xie, and R. Zhang, 2021: Historic Yangtze flooding of 2020 tied to extreme Indian Ocean conditions. PNAS, 118, e2022255118. (top three most cited in physical sciences among 4,237 papers published in PNAS 2021)
